articles.headline: Pandemic Closures Devastate Restaurant Industry’s Middle Class
articles.snippet: A sous-chef’s search for job security shows how cooks, managers and servers at upscale dining establishments have been hit hard by the pandemic.
articles.abstract: A sous-chef’s search for job security shows how cooks, managers and servers at upscale dining establishments have been hit hard by the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the day in September when he was hired as a cook at Fulton Market Kitchen — a restaurant in Chicago featuring shrimp and grits and miso-glazed halibut — Jeff Danaher asked the chef about his plans for the winter.

articles.headline: ‘Small Town, No Hospital’: Covid-19 Is Overwhelming Rural West Texas
articles.snippet: As cases soar in Texas, hospitals are filling up from El Paso to Lubbock. The Big Bend region is especially vulnerable, with just one hospital for 12,000 square miles.
articles.abstract: As cases soar in Texas, hospitals are filling up from El Paso to Lubbock. The Big Bend region is especially vulnerable, with just one hospital for 12,000 square miles.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALPINE, Texas — It is one of the fastest-growing coronavirus hot spots in the nation, but there are no long lines of cars piled up for drive-through testing and no rush of appointments to get swabbed at CVS.

articles.headline: DoorDash Soars in First Day of Trading
articles.snippet: The delivery company’s shares closed at $190 each, 86 percent above its initial public offering price of $102, in a sign of investor appetite.
articles.abstract: The delivery company’s shares closed at $190 each, 86 percent above its initial public offering price of $102, in a sign of investor appetite.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Wall Street loves a pandemic winner.

articles.headline: U.S. and States Say Facebook Illegally Crushed Competition
articles.snippet: Regulators are accusing the company of buying up rising rivals to cement its dominance over social media.
articles.abstract: Regulators are accusing the company of buying up rising rivals to cement its dominance over social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states accused Facebook on Wednesday of buying up its rivals to illegally squash competition, and they called for the deals to be unwound, escalating regulators’ battle against the biggest tech companies in a way that could remake the social media industry.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Fleeing Ethiopians Tell of Ethnic Massacres in Tigray War
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands have sought safety in Sudan, where they gave accounts to Times journalists of a devastating and complex conflict that threatens Ethiopia’s stability.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands have sought safety in Sudan, where they gave accounts to Times journalists of a devastating and complex conflict that threatens Ethiopia’s stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMDAYET, Sudan — The armed men who stopped Ashenafi Hailu along the dirt road dragged him by a noose so they could save bullets.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Legacy on the Line, Mnuchin Gambles by Ending Fed Programs
articles.snippet: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, has clawed back billions from the Federal Reserve, a move Democrats call political but he says is prudent.
articles.abstract: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, has clawed back billions from the Federal Reserve, a move Democrats call political but he says is prudent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his third floor office in the Treasury Department, Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, keeps for posterity a stack of documents that he signed in March authorizing the Federal Reserve’s emergency lending programs as the pandemic roiled financial markets.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: ‘Is Austin on Your List?’: Biden’s Pentagon Pick Rose Despite Barriers to Diversity
articles.snippet: With retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III’s nomination to be the first Black defense secretary, the Pentagon comes face to face with its record as a place where people of color struggle to climb.
articles.abstract: With retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III’s nomination to be the first Black defense secretary, the Pentagon comes face to face with its record as a place where people of color struggle to climb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III, who is on the brink of becoming the first Black man to be secretary of defense, rose to the heights of an American military whose largely white leadership has not reflected the diversity of its rank and file.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Hard to Prove’: Why Antitrust Suits Against Facebook Face Hurdles
articles.snippet: The U.S. and state cases against the social network are far from a slam dunk because the standards of proof are formidable.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and state cases against the social network are far from a slam dunk because the standards of proof are formidable.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states sued Facebook on Wednesday for illegally killing competition and demanded that the company be split apart, lawmakers and public interest groups applauded.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: States Try to Rescue Small Businesses as U.S. Aid Is Snarled
articles.snippet: State governments are offering loans, grants and tax rebates, but budget constraints limit their impact.
articles.abstract: State governments are offering loans, grants and tax rebates, but budget constraints limit their impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the economic recovery faltering and federal aid stalled in Washington, state governments are stepping in to try to help small businesses survive the pandemic winter.
